trailText: Minute-by-minute report: Updates from Wembley as the Seasiders take on the Imps for a place in the Championship. Join Rob Smyth
body:
4.14pm BST

57 min I think I‚Äôm right in saying that, before today, Kenny Dougall had scored two goals in his three seasons in English football. Both his goals were beautifully struck, one with each foot.

4.12pm BST

Mitchell‚Äôs cross from the right took a slight deflection and ran through to Yates, 12 yards out with his back to goal. He thought about a shot, realised it wasn‚Äôt on and played a slow, inviting pass to Dougall on the edge of the D. This time he went with his right foot, drilling a daisy-cutter into the bottom-left corner. That was so sweetly struck.

Updated at 4.15pm BST

4.10pm BST

GOAL! Blackpool 2-1 Lincoln (Dougall 54)

Kenny Dougall scores another superb goal!

4.08pm BST

50 min Embleton plays a slick one-two with Turton and wins a corner. It‚Äôs curled under the bar and punched away a little desperately by Palmer. Moments later, Stewart cracks a bouncing ball over the bar from distance.

4.04pm BST

48 min Ballard is booked for a foul on Rogers.

4.04pm BST

47 min The goalscorer Dougall slides a through ball towards Yates, but Walsh comes across to intercept.

4.02pm BST

46 min Peep peep! Blackpool begin the second half.

3.49pm BST

Half time: Blackpool 1-1 Lincoln

Peep peep! It‚Äôs level at Wembley after a fascinating first half. Lincoln went ahead after 47 seconds through an own goal from Ollie Turton, but they became passive thereafter and allowed Blackpool into the game. They accepted the invitation with a fine equaliser from Kenny Dougall, though there was an unpunished handball by Elliot Embleton in the build up.

Jorge Grant, who was at fault for the Blackpool goal, had earlier hit the crossbar with a fine effort. At the other end Blackpool had a number of shots on target, though all bar Dougall‚Äôs were straight at the keeper Palmer.

Updated at 3.57pm BST

3.45pm BST

45 min Blackpool continue to press for a second goal. Neil Critchley will be thrilled with their calm, authoritative response to that abysmal start.

3.41pm BST

41 min Lincoln may need another half-time brollocking from Michael Appleton. They are hanging on a little bit now, and Palmer has to make another save when Mitchell meets Garbutt‚Äôs cross with a decent header.

3.40pm BST

40 min Embleton, who is looking increasingly dangerous, shoots straight at Palmer from 22 yards.

3.39pm BST

3.39pm BST

39 min Palmer will be annoyed that he was beaten at his near post, but it was a very clean strike from Dougall with his left foot. I think Palmer saw it late as well. He did get a hand on it but couldn‚Äôt keep it out.

Updated at 3.39pm BST

3.37pm BST

37 min A Lincoln free-kick is half cleared to Edun, who sprays over from 25 yards.

Updated at 3.37pm BST

3.37pm BST

36 min Lincoln had been asking for trouble, playing too passively after the first 10 minutes. I suppose it‚Äôs human nature to do that when you go ahead so early in such a vital game, but it‚Äôs not always the best policy.

3.36pm BST

35 min There‚Äôs no VAR in the play-offs. I think the goal would have been disallowed if VAR was in use, though it‚Äôs not certain. You could argue there was enough time between the accidental handball and Dougall‚Äôs goal to invalidate the offence.

3.35pm BST

Yates stole the ball off Grant in the centre circle, moved forward and found Embleton on the edge of the area. He ran into trouble and lost the ball, but then Walsh‚Äôs clearance hit him on the hand and dropped at his feet, 20 yards from goal. He squared it to Dougall, who whistled a superb low past Palmer at the near post.

Updated at 3.38pm BST

3.33pm BST

GOAL! Blackpool 1-1 Lincoln (Dougall 34)

Kenny Dougall equalises for Blackpool - and Lincoln are furious!

Updated at 3.56pm BST

3.33pm BST

32 min ‚ÄúAfternoon Rob,‚Äù says Lee Smith. ‚ÄúPerhaps a confirmed Lancastrian such as Phil Sawyer (5th minute) should remain focused on the Roses drubbing currently being handed out to the White Rose fraternity. Either that or enjoy Brennan Johnson before he heads back to Nottingham!‚Äù

Nottingham via Azerbaijan and Italy, I hope.

3.31pm BST

31 min Brennan Johnson, who has been quiet since that flying start, has started to see more of the ball in the last few minutes. I can‚Äôt wait to see him in the Championship with Forest next season.

3.28pm BST

27 min: Good save from Palmer! The ball ricochets kindly into the path of Yates on the left side of the area. His clever cutback just evades Husband and runs on to Mitchell, who sweeps a first-time shot towards goal with his left foot. It‚Äôs sweetly struck but too close to Palmer, who beats it away.

3.26pm BST

26 min At the other end, Embleton‚Äôs looping cross is headed over by the backpedalling Mitchell. It wasn‚Äôt much of a chance.

3.26pm BST

25 min: Grant hits the bar! Lincoln come so close to making it 2-0. Rogers zips infield from the left and plays a crisp pass into Grant, unmarked 20 yards from goal. He has time to turn and hit an extravagant curling shot that beats Maxwell and clatters off the top of the bar.

Updated at 3.31pm BST

3.23pm BST

23 min Blackpool have had 88 per cent of the possession in the last five minutes. Most of it has been harmless, but it‚Äôs another sign that they have cleared their heads from the shock of that first-minute own-goal.

3.22pm BST

22 min ‚ÄúAny comments on the booing clearly heard on TV,‚Äù says Dave Stevens. ‚ÄúTV commentators ignored it.‚Äù

When the players took a knee? I was typing something about it when Turton scored the own goal, and I got lost in that. But yes, it was audible. It‚Äôs hard to know what to say really.

3.20pm BST

21 min Free-kick to Blackpool, 25 yards from goal. Garbutt strikes it well but straight at Palmer.

3.18pm BST

18 min This is a good spell for Blackpool, who have pinned Lincoln back for the last five or six minutes.

3.17pm BST

16 min Ballard, in his own half, booms a long angled pass to Yates on the left side of the area. He feeds the underlapping Garbutt, whose cross is put behind for a corner by Johnson. This time Walsh heads clear.

3.16pm BST

15 min And now their first shot on target. Mitchell makes a promising run infield from the right but hits a weak effort straight at Palmer.

3.14pm BST

13 min Blackpool win their first corner, another sign they are getting into the game after that desperate. Garbutt swings it in, Hopper heads clear.

3.11pm BST

11 min Blackpool enjoy their first extended spell of possession. Eventually Husband drives a long pass towards Yates, who is just beaten to the ball by the alert keeper Alex Palmer.

3.09pm BST

9 min The resulting free-kick is curled to the near post, where Walsh heads over from six yards. That was a fairly decent chance; he couldn‚Äôt quite get over the ball.

3.08pm BST

9 min Garbutt is booked for clattering Johnson, the Welsh winger who has made a sensational start to the game.

Updated at 3.09pm BST

3.07pm BST

3.06pm BST

6 min Brennan Johnson has made a superb start on the right wing. His low cross is put behind for Lincoln‚Äôs first corner. It‚Äôs curled towards the penalty spot and headed away by Husband. Never mind clearing with the head; Blackpool urgently need to clear their heads.

3.05pm BST

5 min ‚ÄúAfternoon, Rob,‚Äù says Phil Sawyer. ‚ÄúAs The Only Blackpool Lad In Lincoln, I‚Äôm keeping my head down this afternoon. I‚Äôm stocked up on tangerines should a baying mob storm Sawyer Towers post-match, hungry for blood. If you never hear from me again, know that I fought to the last squirt of citric acid and stick of rock. Seasiders!‚Äù

3.05pm BST

3 min What a nightmare for Ollie Turton. His brain and body just weren‚Äôt in sync. Updated at 3.08pm BST

3.02pm BST

3.01pm BST

GOAL! Blackpool 0-1 Lincoln (Turton own goal 1)

Lincoln are ahead after 47 seconds!

Updated at 3.12pm BST

3.00pm BST

1 min Peep peep! Lincoln, in their black away strip, kick off from right to left. Blackpool are wearing tangerine.

2.58pm BST

It‚Äôs a gorgeous day at Wembley, and the 10,000 fans in attendance are making a rousing noise.

2.57pm BST

The players line up for the national anthem, and what a timeless cracker it is.

Updated at 2.59pm BST

2.50pm BST

With ten minutes to go until kick off, here‚Äôs a reminder of the teams.

Blackpool (4-2-3-1) Maxwell; Turton, Ballard, Husband, Garbutt; Dougall, Stewart; Mitchell, Embleton, Anderson; Yates.
Substitutes: Moore, Gabriel, Ekpiteta, Thornley, Ward, Hamilton, Madine.

Lincoln (4-1-4-1) Palmer; Poole, Eyoma, Walsh, Edun; Bridcutt; Johnson, McGrandles, Grant, Rogers; Hopper.
Substitutes: Long, Montsma, Sanders, Scully, Bramall, Morton, Anderson.

Referee Tony Harrington.

2.49pm BST

And here‚Äôs the Lincoln manager Michael Appleton ‚Äú[On their delayed arrival] Hopefully it won‚Äôt affect us too much. These things can happen with London traffic - I think there was a big accident and one of the roads was shut. Listen, the lads will be ready by 3 o‚Äôclock.

‚ÄúWe‚Äôve got to come out of the traps - we know Blackpool will start fast and we need to compete with them. The longer the game goes on and stays close, that‚Äôs when we start to back ourselves. We always tend to finish strongly. But we know Blackpool are very organised, efficient and hard to beat.‚Äù

2.40pm BST

The thoughts of Blackpool manager Neil Critchley

‚ÄúI really feel for the kid [Ellis Simms]. It was basically the last kick of the training session yesterday - he took a penalty and felt something go. It‚Äôs heartbreaking. He was going to start today, so for that to be taken away in such cruel circumstances is a body blow for us and even more so for him.

‚ÄúWe‚Äôve had key players out all season. We‚Äôre adaptable and flexible in our thinking, and we‚Äôre ready - we‚Äôre good to go. We‚Äôve had a good rest since the semi-final. Other than the heat [it‚Äôs around 20 degrees], we‚Äôll be fine!‚Äù

Updated at 2.41pm BST

2.37pm BST

Lincoln didn‚Äôt arrive at Wembley until 2.15pm, according to David Prutton on Sky Sports. I can‚Äôt speak for the Lincoln players but I would hate that. I panic if I‚Äôm not in the MBM dungeon an hour before kick-off, so I‚Äôd be all over the show if I was a player.

2.14pm BST

Blackpool had a fairly comfortable passage to Wembley, beating Oxford 6-3 on aggregate in their semi-final.

Related: Blackpool through to League One play-off final after 3-3 draw with Oxford

Lincoln‚Äôs progress was much more dramatic. They recovered from a desperate first half at the Stadium of Light last Saturday to eliminate Sunderland in memorable style.

Related: Lincoln reach League One play-off final after Hopper‚Äôs header at Sunderland

Updated at 2.26pm BST

2.10pm BST

Pre-match reading

Related: Lincoln‚Äôs Michael Appleton: ‚ÄòMy time with the Oystons was difficult as any‚Äô

2.00pm BST

The teams are in

A blow for Blackpool: the in-form Ellis Simms, on loan from Everton, picked up a knock in training and doesn‚Äôt even make the bench.

Conor McGrandles, an influential substitute in Lincoln‚Äôs semi-final win over Sunderland, starts in place of Anthony Scully.

Updated at 2.21pm BST

1.41pm BST

Preamble

There are umpteen things that make the play-offs so compelling, even for the neutral. They provide agony and ecstasy, to use the most popular clich√©, but also drama, controversy, desperation and occasionally the highest farce. Most of all, they give us brilliant, sometimes legendary stories. And in today‚Äôs League One play-off final at Wembley, we are guaranteed a feelgood belter of a tale.

In the black corner, we have Lincoln City. If they are promoted, they will play in the second tier for the first time since 1961, and continue the spectacular rise of a club that was in the National League as recently as 2017. In the tangerine corner, we have Blackpool FC. They are recovering from 32 years of ever increasing misery under the revolting ownership of Owen Oyston. He was finally removed a cojple of years ago, and Blackpool‚Äôs storming run into the play-offs - they were 15th at the end of January - has enhanced the feeling of a club reborn.

There‚Äôs plenty of neutral goodwill towards both clubs and their impressive young coaches, Neil Critchley at Blackpool and Michael Appleton at Lincoln. The only shame is that they can‚Äôt both be promoted.

Kick off 3pm

4.15pm BST

Ah, and Saba has just broken to lead 2-0 in set two. She may just have broken the back of Konjuh.

4.13pm BST

On Lenglen, Sabalenka, the women‚Äôs number three seed, has just taken a tight first set off Konjuh 6-4. I was watching Nishikori on my second screen but have just switched to this one so will have a look at how it‚Äôs going.

4.11pm BST

Elsewhere, Dimitrov is nearly there, 4-1 up on Giron in set three, while while Nishikori has won set three and now leads Giannessi 2-1.

4.09pm BST

Yeah, Andujar is nervous and quickly faces break-back point ... so carts an ace down the T! That is superb behaviour! Thiem then goes long with a return and Andujar has another set point! He‚Äôll need to do it with a second serve too, and Thiem looks primed ... to cloud an inside-out forehand wide! We‚Äôve go waselves a decider! Andujar 4-6 5-7 6-3 6-4 Thiem

4.07pm BST

How are your nerves, Pablo Andujar? When his first serve goes in he‚Äôs winning 60 percent of points and he finds one first up, but soon has to claw his way back to 30-all. Then Thiem sends a return long and it‚Äôs set point ... but Andujar, behind in the next rally, tries a lob, which Thiem punishes. Deuce it is....

4.03pm BST

Thiem rinses through a hold, forcing Andujar to serve for it. Hang on, mates! Andujar 4-6 5-7 6-3 5-4 Thiem

4.00pm BST

Andujar gets himself to 40-0 but then Thiem manages to get to within a point and tries a drop ... Andujar reads and takes control of the rally, then a shot later, a leaping backhand, flicked along the net, gives him 5-3!

3.56pm BST

Naomi Osaka fined ¬£15,000 for not attending her post-match press conference

I wonder where we‚Äôll go from here. The tournament organisers asked her to reconsider and tried to check on her well-being, but no conversation happened.

Updated at 4.04pm BST

3.55pm BST

Thiem is back into this, yanking back a break then saving a break point before holding; he‚Äôs within a game of Andujar, and it feels like momentum is switching. It‚Äôs 4-3 in the third now, with Thiem leading by two sets to one.

3.50pm BST

A quick once-over the other courts shows me that Nishikori is a break up on Gianessi, who levelled the match at 1-1 just a bit ago, whie Dimitrov leads Giron 6-2 6-4. I‚Äôd love to see old Grigzy do something, but at 30 his time to win a major has probably gone. In fairness, it must be pretty nauseating to still have the players you were meant to succeed winning stuff.

3.46pm BST

‚ÄúAndujar is indeed playing well,‚Äù says Jacques Derek Charlwood, ‚Äúbut puffing his cheeks with every point. One wonders if as you get older ( he is 35 versus Thiem‚Äôs 24) you regulate your first serves to save energy.‚Äù

I‚Äôm sure you do lots to keep yourself fresh, but I‚Äôd wager that there‚Äôs nothing better for that than the game flowing with you - as it is now for Andujar.

3.45pm BST

Andujar, who looks not unlike Mikel Arteta, is really piecing Thiem up here, covering his angles and picking his drops. In this latest game, he reads a forehand to this backhand corner, skids after it and carts a winner cross-court! Yeah, Andujar is nervous and quickly faces break-back point ... so carts an ace down the T! That is superb behaviour! Thiem then goes long with a return and Andujar has another set point! He‚Äôll need to do it with a second serve too, and Thiem looks primed ... to cloud an inside-out forehand wide! We‚Äôve go waselves a decider! Andujar 4-6 5-7 6-3 6-4 Thiem How are your nerves, Pablo Andujar? When his first serve goes in he‚Äôs winning 60 percent of points and he finds one first up, but soon has to claw his way back to 30-all. Then Thiem sends a return long and it‚Äôs set point ... but Andujar, behind in the next rally, tries a lob, which Thiem punishes. Deuce it is.... Thiem rinses through a hold, forcing Andujar to serve for it. Hang on, mates! Andujar 4-6 5-7 6-3 5-4 Thiem Andujar gets himself to 40-0 but then Thiem manages to get to within a point and tries a drop ... Andujar reads and takes control of the rally, then a shot later, a leaping backhand, flicked along the net, gives him 5-3! I wonder where we‚Äôll go from here. The tournament organisers asked her to reconsider and tried to check on her well-being, but no conversation happened. Thiem is back into this, yanking back a break then saving a break point before holding; he‚Äôs within a game of Andujar, and it feels like momentum is switching. It‚Äôs 4-3 in the third now, with Thiem leading by two sets to one. A quick once-over the other courts shows me that Nishikori is a break up on Gianessi, who levelled the match at 1-1 just a bit ago, whie Dimitrov leads Giron 6-2 6-4. I‚Äôd love to see old Grigzy do something, but at 30 his time to win a major has probably gone. In fairness, it must be pretty nauseating to still have the players you were meant to succeed winning stuff. ‚ÄúAndujar is indeed playing well,‚Äù says Jacques Derek Charlwood, ‚Äúbut puffing his cheeks with every point. One wonders if as you get older ( he is 35 versus Thiem‚Äôs 24) you regulate your first serves to save energy.‚Äù I‚Äôm sure you do lots to keep yourself fresh, but I‚Äôd wager that there‚Äôs nothing better for that than the game flowing with you - as it is now for Andujar. Andujar, who looks not unlike Mikel Arteta, is really piecing Thiem up here, covering his angles and picking his drops. In this latest game, he reads a forehand to this backhand corner, skids after it and carts a winner cross-court! Eventually, we get to deuce and Andujar raises break point; Thiem really needs a first serve, can‚Äôt find one, and then from the backhand corner, looks down the line and slashes wide! It looks a lot like we‚Äôll get a deciderhere, and the number four seed is in shtuck! Andujar 4-6 5-7 6-3 4-1 Thiem Three games in row for Andujar, who‚Äôs seeing it very nicely right about now. He carts a forehand pass cross-court, and that‚Äôs 3-1 to him, Thiem by two sets to one. ‚ÄúDropping our Hs would give us Enman and Ewitt, Enin, Ingiss and Antuchova,‚Äù notes Andrew Benton. ‚ÄúEven with their Hs restored, they‚Äôre all azbeens. Are there no H‚Äôs playing at top table these days?‚Äù I guess not, though I do laugh every time I hear someone call Hazza Kane or Maguire ‚ÄúHaitch.‚Äù I guess there‚Äôs this lad though. On court 14, Gianessi has won a breaker to four, levelling his match with Nishikori at one set all; on court seven, Dimitrov took the first set against Giron and we‚Äôre 3-3 in the second. So what‚Äôs going on on Chatrier?! Thiem swipes a forehand wide and Andujar, who‚Äôs playing really well now, is a break up in set four! Elsewhere, Fucsovics is serving for the match against Simon and Dimitrov is a set up on Giron. That was a really enjoyable match, and you‚Äôve got to admire Kecmanovic‚Äôs role in it. It‚Äôs been a tricky few years for him, but he was a very good junior and at 21 still has time to grow. But now it‚Äôs over! Kecmanovic reads a second serve and punches back a winner, then Evans goes long on a desperate and high forehand volley! Kecmanovic plays Moutet or Djere next; Evans, meanwhile, is imropving but has now gone out in round 1 in three of the last four majors. Good Evans. Again, his serve is dicey and from in front, he finds himself facing match point at 30-40; a gigantic forehand elicits an error, then an ace takes advantage to give him advantage. Kecmanovic, though, plays a terrific point ‚Äì in fairness, both players do ‚Äì swapping forehands and gets before a drop-shot brings us back to deuce. This is great stuff. Why have they changed the service marker on the telly scoreboard from a dot to a new paragraph mark? Kecmanovic has tightened, and flings a forehand long to give Evans 30-all before netting a backhand! And when Evans finds a deep return, he goes long! That‚Äôs four straight points for the British number 1, and he‚Äôs still in this! Kecmanovic 1-6 6-3 6-3 5-4 Evans Kecmanovic will now serve for the match, a circumstance that did not look likely when he lost the first set 6-1. Now then! Andujar struggles back and holds to take the third set! Thiem was a bit lax there, and as punishment he‚Äôll have to charge about for a bit longer. Andujar 4-6 5-7 6-3 Thiem Kecmanovic has only won nine matches so far this season, but he‚Äôs found his form now and a comfortable enough consolidation means that Evans will now serve to stay in the match at 2-5 in the fourth. Now then. Andujar breaks Thiem to love and is now serving for the third set ... and is 0-30 down. It takes a while, but Kecmanovic wins his third game in a row and now needs only two more for the win. Evans had loads of chances to level the set but couldn‚Äôt strong two points together once he‚Äôd won three to come back from 0-40. Kecmanovic 1-6 6-3 6-3 4-2 Evans She plays Vesnina or Govortsova next. Superb from Evans, roaring back from 0-40 to win three straight points, the last of them an ace ‚Äì his first of the set. He then hands Kecmanovic a chance by cracking into the net-cord, but the consequent pass is no good and we recline into a round of deuces. Brutal. Credit to Andujar, he‚Äôs not going away. He leads 3-2 in set three while, back in the women‚Äôs competition, Kvitova has bolted and leads Minnen 4-0 in the decider. Ach! Evans played his better stuff for a while but Kecmanovic is coming again, breaking back before speeding through a love hold! We‚Äôre back on serve in set four. Kecmanovic 1-6 6-3 6-3 3-2 Evans As such, here‚Äôs a piece on the unique joy of Murray, and here he is in Joy of Six: cool sports stats. Email! ‚ÄúI know it shouldn‚Äôt matter,‚Äù writes Simon McMahon, ‚Äúbut for me tennis just hasn‚Äôt been the same without Andy Murray. I know Evans, Edmund, Konta and Norrie are still carrying the flag for GB tennis, and it seems Dan is channeling his inner Andy today, but my wish is that we can see Andy himself win a few more matches at Grand Slams before retirement, maybe making the second week at Wimbledon with a signature Murray performance, battling back from two sets down, having to beat himself as much as his opponent, full of fist pumps, emotion, drama and of course some sublime shot-making. He‚Äôs earned the right to go out on his own terms I think. I don‚Äôt think we‚Äôve ever taken him for granted, but it could be a long time before we see his like again. Scotland‚Äôs greatest ever sportsperson? I‚Äôd say he‚Äôs in the top one.‚Äù I feel you ‚Äì I can‚Äôt think of many individual sportsfolk I‚Äôve loved as much as Murray, who is one of the most obviously top blokes I‚Äôve never met. I can‚Äôt think of many Scots anywhere near him ‚Äì Alan Wells is one, Law, Dalglish and Rose Reilly others. I‚Äôve got a personal soft spot for Jojo Calderwood, but yeah, I‚Äôd have Muzz, for the martchplaying but also for the man. Evans is breathing hard - it‚Äôs warm out there - as he works his arse off for the second break. He gets a chance too, but Kecmanovic finds a first serve-forehand combo that removes the opportunity, and following a further succession of deuces, closes out the game to get on the board in set three. Kecmanovic 1-6 6-3 6-3 0-2 Evans On Lenglen, Kvitova has taken the breaker so she and Minnen ‚Äì a Belgian qualifier ‚Äì will play a decider. Minnen 7-6(3) (5)5-7 Kvitova Evans shanks a return that gives Kecmanovic deuce and naturally abuses the court with some choice Anglo-Saxon; quite right too. He‚Äôs struggling to get free points on his serve here, but he‚Äôs fighting like Chelsea and Man City fans in Oporto. Eventually, it pays off too, a second serve out wide cleaned up with a ferocious forehand. This is a really fun match now. Kecmanovic 1-6 6-3 6-3 0-2 Evans Elsewhere, Minnen leads Kvitova, the number 11 seed, 7-6; they‚Äôre playing a breaker in set two. Fucsovics, meanwhile, leads Simon 6-4 6-1 and Pella is sorting Galan 6-3 7-6(4). Thiem closes out the second set, and now leads Andujar 6-4 7-5. Evans changes from blue to green, which should sort things ... and, for now, it has! He glides a backhand return cross-court and when Kecmanovic‚Äôs riposte clips the net cord, he shovels a winner into the corner. If these two can hit a vein at the same time, the conclusion of this match could be great. Kecmanovic 1-6 6-3 6-3 0-1 Evans Less surprising is what happens on Chatrier, Thiem turning it up to break to love. He‚Äôll now serve for the set (again). This is superb from Kecmanovic! Just as Evans thinks he found himself again, he‚Äôs broken again, and that‚Äôs 2-1 to the Serb! Kecmanovic 1-6 6-3 6-3 Evans Well who saw that coming? From 30-0 up, Thiem allows Andujar back into the game and it costs him a break! We‚Äôre back on serve in set two! Andujar 4-6 5-5 Thiem Excellent from Evans, coming in behind a telling forehand to despatch a high backhand volley at the net; that gives him two break points, and a wild, swiped backhand keeps the set alive. Kecmanovic 1-6 6-3 5-3 Evans Meanwhile, on Chatrier, Thiem is serving for 2-0; Andujar has never won a match from 0-2 down. He gets there in the end! Kecmanovic is splattering Evans‚Äô serve at the moment, and after change of ends, he‚Äôll rely on his own to go 2-1 in front. Kecmanovic 1-6 6-3 5-2 Evans Thanks John. Evans and Kecmanovic are wrestling through a brutal game that Evans must win; the longer it goes, the more that is so. Kecmanovic has the latest of various advantages ... and Evans saves break point number seven with a large forehand and put-away. And with that, it‚Äôs back to Daniel with Evans v Kecmanovic so finely poised. It‚Äôs a tad windy in Paris, and Evans continues to put up a fight against Kecmanovic‚Äôs serve. He has a break point at deuce but crashes his shot into the net. Then he lands another with a smash. He can‚Äôt keep the ball in on the next one so back to deuce it goes. Then comes another, and Evans continues to chat to himself. Then comes a huge rally, and Evans slowly moves his opponent around the court to break back to 2-4. Now he must serve this one out. Kecmanovic breaks straight back, unaffected by Evans‚Äô mini-revival, he‚Äôs 4-1 on up on the Brit and looks assured of the third set. Evans is still living, and he breaks back, charging from the back of the court to leather a winner. It‚Äôs still 1-3 in the third but he has hope. His problem is that he is having to do most of his playing from the very back of the court. Going with serve between Thiem and Andujar on Philippe Chatrier. It‚Äôs a most even contest. There‚Äôs a Serbian contingent roaring on Kecmanovic, but nobody roaring on Dan Evans the plucky Brit. He‚Äôs still doing plenty of talking to himself. And more rude words. He‚Äôs down 3-0 and in deep trouble. Kecmanovic serves out to get 2-0 up and now Evans is swearing at the umpire, complaining that people are being let into the court while he is serving. He used the f-word. Naughty boy, and he‚Äôs getting a spanking here. Dan Evans throwing a wobbler? He is interrupted by a voice from outside the court as he goes to serve, catches the ball. ‚ÄúAstonishing, mate, astonishing,‚Äù he shouts at persons unknown. And Kecmanovic has a run on him, breaking in the very first game of the third set. Some big names playing in tonight‚Äôs inaugural evening session. Thiem serves out, and wins the first set 6-4, walloping a forehand winner. Kecmanovic lands himself three set points with some excellent play, and eventually serves to love. 1-6 6-3 now, and Evans has trouble on his hands. Kecmanovic, at 5-2 up, attempts to break Evans but the Englishman forces him to serve to level the sets. Evans double faults and leads 40-30, only to win the game with a great forehand. Thiem has control of the first set against Andujar as he goes 5-3 up. His opponent seems flustered; his good play is going unrewarded. He holds the next one and lands his first ace in the process. Thiem will serve out the set. Some resistance from Evans, real speed around the court as he tries to stop Kecmanovic breaking again, and he holds to take it back 2-4 in the second set. A Tim Henman-style punch of the air, but without the blowing on the fingers. Some actualit√©. It goes 4-1 to Kecmanovic with a good hold of serve. Evans needs to start picking things back up or he will be in trouble in the third set, too. Hello there, here for the next hour. Andujar just saved six break points from Thiem, and it‚Äôs 2-3 to the Frenchman. Evans just got one back, so it‚Äôs 1-3 in the second set with Kecmanovic. Right, I‚Äôm away for some fress. John Brewin with narrate you through the next little bit. Kecmanovic is reading Evans now, chasing down his drops and generally dominating ‚Äì this is boiling up nicely. Kecmanovic 1-6 3-0 Evans Thiem is such a beautiful mover, and already Andujar is puffing out his cheeks in resignation. But 1-3 and break point down, he runs around a forehand to drive a winner down the line; this game has been going nearly six minutes now, the majority of it Andujar saving break points, and we‚Äôve now been going 11 minutes. Andujar 1-3 Thiem Superb from Kecmanovic, who holds then reads an Evans drop for 0-30 before, on break point, swiping a backhand winner cross-court! Do we got ourselves a ball-game? Kecmanovic 1-6 2-0 Evans Kecmanovic is making a game of the games now, but he‚Äôs still getting absolutely served; Evans, who beat Djokovic at Monte Carlo last month, is looking lovely and takes the first set in short order. Kecmanovic 1-6 Evans Back on Chatrier, Andujar had a break-back point against Thiem but failed to convert; he‚Äôs on the baord, though, 2-1 down in set one. Kecmanovic fights hard in the sixth game of the match and he‚Äôs in it now, a banging forehand down the line resolving a succession of deuces. Kecmanovic 1-5 Evans On court seven, Roberto Bautista Agut ‚Äì the number 11 seed ‚Äì is underway. If he‚Äôd played in the 80s or 90s he might‚Äôve won one of these in the way that Muster, Bruguera, Gomez, Moya and Kafelnikov all did. But here we are. He trials Vilella Martinez 4-3 on serve. Meanwhile, on Chatrier, a dominant first game from Thiem sees him break Andujar. Evans has got into stride quickly here and looks to have Kecmanovic‚Äôs number. There‚Äôs not much pop on the Serb‚Äôs serve which is allowing yerman to climb right into points, and this first set is almost over. Kecmanovic 0-4 Evans Fognini has beaten Barrera 4,1 and 4. The number 27 seed plays Simon or, more likely, Fucsovics next. Those two tussle on Mathieu presently; Kovinivic has done for Burel 6-3 7-6(8) and must now contemplate Osaka. Anyhow, while I was busy wondering what my girlfriend wife would say if I publicly challenged her ability to have it, Evans was busy holding and breaking. Kecmanovic 0-2 Evans Just last week, Thiem noted that living in a bubble has helped Evans, given he‚Äôs previously struggled with the demands of the professional athlete‚Äôs lifestyle; Evans was having none of it, retorting that he‚Äôd sorted himself well before the pandemic started. ‚ÄúI must be out partying a lot, yeah,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúI‚Äôve done all right outside of the bubble as well. I must have improved a lot inside it for him to say that. I travel with my girlfriend every week. It‚Äôs not like you can go out partying with your girlfriend every week. It‚Äôs not that I was on my own and single and going nuts when there weren‚Äôt bubbles. It‚Äôs a strange comment, isn‚Äôt it?‚Äù Evans and Kecmanovic are knocking up.... Next on Chatrier: the number four seed and defeated finalist in 2018 and 2019, Dominic Thiem, begins his next assault on the trophy. He meets Pablo Andujar. A couple more results: in the men‚Äôs competition, Carreno Busta has rinsed Gombos 3,4, and 3, whole in the women‚Äôs, Tomljanovic has sorted Kozlova 2 and 4. Osaka hasn‚Äôt played a lot lately but she looked pretty good today. I don‚Äôt think her footwork is good enough to win here ‚Äì yet ‚Äì but her ball-striking was on-point and the relative closeness of the match is down to how well Tig played. Osaka meets Bogdan next. Osaka hollers a come on as she makes 4-2 in the breaker ‚Äì the ball makes such a lush thump off the middle of her forehand. An error from Tig quickly gives her 5-2 ... but consecutive unforced errors and we‚Äôre back on serve. Briefly. Here ceom two more match points.... Next on court six, we‚Äôve got Dan Evans, the British number one, against Minomir Kecmanovic. She meets Burel or Kovinivic next; Kovinivic won the first set 6-3 and it‚Äôs 2-2 in the second. Tig is competing hard here, but with a point for a breaker clips over another second serve of questionable power and Osaka quickly punishes. She may well regret that ... but no! A forehand clattered down the line saves the match point that follows, and a fine kicker helps her raise advantage, ceded when an inside-out forehand drops marginally wide ... but what a lob she finds when in front the next time! Tig 4-6 6-6 Osaka Fognini has taken that second set against Barrere to lead 6-4 6-1 1-0 (with a break). On court six, Badosa and Davis are playing a breaker in a topsy-turvy second set; Badosa won the first. But look at Kalinina! She reels off two points in short order and it turns out you can‚Äôt loz the first five games of a set and expect to win. She meets Collins or Wang next; Wang has just levelled the match at one set all. ...and Kerber saves it with a glorious backhand slice drop-shot! Egalit√©! Osaka is whacking it hard now, but Tig is just about sticking with her, while Kalinina finds a devastating forehand to give herself 30-0 against Kerber; she‚Äôs nearly there. Back to Chatrier, Tig misses a huge chance with a half-court volley that would‚Äôve got her 15-30; seconds later, the game has gone and Osaka, 5-4 up in the second, needs just one more. Kerber, meanwhile, soon makes 30-all; Kalinina steps on the spot to try and shake her tightness, then serves a double. Eesh. She makes deuce though, then hits through the ball beautifully to raise match point... Fognini is bolting; the number 27 seed came from behind to take the first set of Barrere, but now leads 4-1 in the second. A monstrous forehand down the line breaks Kalinina to 15; it‚Äôs taken a while but Kerber is motoring. Still, the qualifier will have one more chance to eject her before we‚Äôre back on serve ‚Äì but first, Kerber must hold. Kalinina 6-2 5-3 Kerber Tig is hanging in there well, but Osaka holds for 3-2, while Kerber has won a second game and Kalinina will now serve for the match a second time. At change of ends, she puts a towel over her head to get into the correct frame of mind. Pablo Carreno Busta, the number 12 seed and a clay-court specialist, has taken set two against Norbert Gombos; he now leads 6-3 6-4 0-1. Kerber has won a game! Kalinina now leads 6-2 5-1. Some reading on Edberg. Goodness me, Tig just dispensed the weakest second serve I‚Äôve ever seen, short, skipping up off the clay, and duly marmalised by Osaka. In commentary, they reckon Sampras had the best second-serve in men‚Äôs history ‚Äì shout from me for Edberg‚Äôs kicker ‚Äì and Durie mentions Barty in the women‚Äôs game. Anyhow, Tig survives a break point to hold. Tig 4-6 2-2 It took a while, but Fognini has fought back to take the first set from Barrere, 6-4; Kalinina now leads Kerber ‚Äì who‚Äôs won every major but this one ‚Äì 6-2 4-0. Tossing those opportunities has not not gone down well with Osaka, who powers through a break to love, seizing the first set and sealing it with a colossal forehand racing forward. Tig 4-6 Osaka Updates from the women‚Äôs side: Kozlova 2-6 Tomljanovic, Cocciaretto 1-6 2-3 Bogdan, Collins 6-2 1-1 Wang Have a look! Kalinina breaks Kerber in the first game of the second set and quickly consolidates, while a double fault helps Tig earn a break-back point; Osaka impatiently whips a forehand long, and we‚Äôre back on serve! Tig 4-5 Osaka Tig saves three set points, forcing Osaka to serve for the first set, while Badosa has taken hers against Davis, 6-2. When they‚Äôre done on court six, Dan Evans will have a go; he plays the Serb, Miomir Kecmanoviƒá. Kerber couldn‚Äôt do enough, and after a succession of deuces during which she saved a set point with a net cord, Kalinina comes through 6-2. Carreno Busta, the number 12 seed, has rinsed through the first set against Gombos 6-3 and now trails 0-1 in the second, on serve; I‚Äôm not quite sure how they‚Äôve managed 10 games so quickly, but they have. By way of comparison, Barrere leads Fognini 3-2, still with the break he took early doors. Osaka isn‚Äôt a natural mover on clay but she‚Äôs hitting it very nicely indeed, especially with feet planted. She‚Äôs won 15 out of 16 on serve, and her second straight love-game leaves her close to the first set. Tig 2-5 Osaka Yeah, time‚Äôs up. Kerber has roused herself to claw back a break. It might not save this set for her, but if she maintains her current level, she‚Äôll be reet. Kalinina 5-2 Kerber Out of the corner of my eye, I‚Äôm also watching Paula Badosa, the number 33 seed, playing Lauren Davis; Badosa is a Manhattan-born Spaniard and won the girls‚Äô singles in 2015. She‚Äôs looking good out there, leading 4-2. Elsewhere, Bogdan has taken the first set against Cocciaretto, 6-1; Fognini is a break down to Barrere; and Tomljanovic leads Kozlova 3-0. It‚Äôs all going wrong for Kerber, who now trails Kalinina 5-0. Under an umbrella ‚Äì what a lovely sight that is ‚Äì she takes some deep breaths while having a serious word with herself. Yeah, Osaka is grooving, greeting a decent first serve with a belter of a cross-court return to raise break point. But Tig yanks her in and Osaka stutter-slides in to botch a slice of her own ... but no matter. She‚Äôs piecing Tig up here, and a booming forehand nails her fourth advantage. Tig 0-2 Osaka I‚Äôm also watching Angelique Kerber, who‚Äôs not a great clay artist and is 0-2 down to Anhelina Kalinina, the qualifer. Meanwhile, on Chatrier, Jo Durie discusses how brilliant the current standard of women‚Äôs tennis is, and she‚Äôs right. I suppose I might slightly disagree, she‚Äôll be devo‚Äôd to learn, because there‚Äôs no dominant champion at the peak of their powers. Perhaps Osaka will be become that, but otherwise there are so many who are so good, and when you stick on a match you‚Äôve not a clue what‚Äôs going to happen, and that‚Äôs a beautiful thing. I‚Äôm really looking forward to seeing the improvements Osaka has made on clay, and she saves a break point in the opening game of the match. Tig 0-1 Osaka. On Chatrier, Naomi Osaka will be underway in une minute. Here‚Äôs Tumaini Carayol on her big call. Well, on the show courts - there‚Äôs plenty else besides. Chatrier Tig v Osaka [2] Andujar v Thiem [4] Azarenka [15] v Kuznetsova Tsitsipas [5] v Chardy Lenglen Fognini [27] v Barrere Minnen [Q] v Kvitova [11] Konjuh [Q] v Sabalneka [3] Zverev [6] v Otte [Q] Mathieu Burel v Kovinivic Fucsovics v Simon Moutet v Djere Dodin v Keys [23] It‚Äôs been an enervating, affirming winter slog, but we made it, and with the first ball tossed this morning, the summer of sport ‚Äì the ridiculous summer of sport ‚Äì is upon us. And you can be absolutely certain that we‚Äôll take it. Most importantly, each of the show courts will house up to 1000 fans a day for each of the first 10 days ‚Äì and hopefully more thereafter. They, like the rest of us, will be wondering whether this, finally, is the year that Rafael Nadal finally runs out of road; Novak Djokovic, Dominic Thiem, Stefanos Tsitsipas and Daniil Medvedev will be hoping so, but it will only be a hope. Meanwhile and as has become the fashion ‚Äì sorry, le mode ‚Äì no one has a clue what‚Äôll happen in the women‚Äôs side. Iga Swiatek is the defending champion and if she hits a vein she‚Äôll be hard to stop, but there are just so many others who might do likewise that anyone who thinks they know is lying. I cannot wait. Play: 11pm local, 10am BST

body:
Samantha Scott does not miss her daily commutes in London, particularly ‚Äúthe dread of having to wake up and get on the tube, and heading into work sweaty and flustered. I‚Äôm still waking up at 6 or 7am, but I‚Äôm able to go for a walk on the beach before I start work.‚Äù

When she and her partner Chris Cerra arrive with their luggage in a new city, they can easily be mistaken for tourists. But they are part of a new generation of ‚Äúdigital nomads‚Äù who hop from country to country to live and work.

The global shift to flexible working triggered by the Covid-19 pandemic means more people are considering ditching their long-term homes to flit around the world, working from their laptops, tablets or smartphones.

Last week, a report from Airbnb entitled Travel & Living showed that 11% of the company‚Äôs long-term stay bookers in 2021 have reported living a nomadic lifestyle, and 5% plan to give up their main homes.

Delia Colantuono, a 31-year-old freelance translator from Rome, became a digital nomad five years ago when it was not a ‚Äúbig thing‚Äù.

She has now lived on all five continents and says the nomadic lifestyle is ‚Äúnot just for rich people ‚Äì it‚Äôs for anyone who can work remotely and wants to do it‚Äù.

Many places are keen to attract long-term visitors, meaning bargains can be found. Colantuono has been renting a villa in Fuerteventura in the Canary Islands with three other nomads for ‚Ç¨450 (¬£390) a month each.

Cerra, 28, a research and development technical consultant for a finance boutique, lived in several cramped flatshares in London and later rented an apartment with a friend for ¬£1,000 a month per person. Since he became a nomad, accommodation costs have varied from ¬£300 in Asia to more than ¬£1,000 in Stockholm, Sweden.

High-speed wifi is top of the wishlist for nomads, followed by good workspace ‚Äì desks or a large dining room table ‚Äì a decent kitchen, and comfortable beds.

Chanin Kaye, 51, and her partner Jason Melton, 46, are six months into a seven-year road trip from Mexico to Argentina, staying for about a month in each city. They decided to leave their home in Seattle because they love travelling, and to save money to pay off large student debts.

‚ÄúSeattle has a very high cost of living,‚Äù Kaye says. ‚ÄúWe had a large house with two other roommates ‚Äì and we were still paying $2,400 (¬£1,690) a month including utilities. Here [in Mexico] we never pay more than $1,200 all inclusive, and often less.‚Äù

They realised during the pandemic that they could keep in touch with their grown kids remotely ‚Äúand feel close even when we aren‚Äôt physically close‚Äù.

Melton left his sales job and the couple now run an accounting business remotely together that Kaye has set up. ‚ÄúWe work all day and go on adventures all weekend,‚Äù she says.

Kaye reckons the couple save 70% by living on the road, and wants to be debt free within five years ‚Äì and buy a property somewhere eventually.

Colantuono and others are aware of the environmental impact of their jetsetter lifestyle, and want to settle down eventually. Several people, writing on a Facebook digital nomads forum with 15,500 members, say age is not a barrier but stress the importance of being fit and healthy; and one says a drawback of this lifestyle might be a sense of rootlessness.

There do not appear to be many digital nomad families with children; traditionally, only a few families ‚Äì who usually home-school ‚Äì have travelled the globe. Erin Elizabeth Wells, a 41-year-old productivity consultant from Massachusetts, started travelling around the US with her husband and daughter Eleanor, who is nearly four now, in October 2018, and says they are a ‚Äúworld schooling family‚Äù.

Related: The Guardian view on working from home: a new social divide | Editorial

Travelling with family means they travel slowly, but that means they make friends everywhere they visit, she adds. They are living in Airbnbs or other full-furnished rentals and ‚Äúplan to continue indefinitely until there‚Äôs some reason our family needs something else‚Äù.

headline: Family accuses East Surrey hospital of letting woman ‚Äòwaste away‚Äô
standfirst: Coroner ruled that neglect contributed to Linda Doherty‚Äôs death from starvation amid blunders in 2017
trailText: Coroner ruled that neglect contributed to Linda Doherty‚Äôs death from starvation amid blunders in 2017
body:
The family of a woman who starved to death in hospital claim staff ‚Äúlacked humanity‚Äù and let her ‚Äúwaste away‚Äù amid an array of medical blunders over her feeding.

The care Linda Doherty received was so poor that, in an unusual move, the coroner who investigated her death ruled that neglect by East Surrey hospital had contributed to it.

Marcus Doherty, her husband, said: ‚ÄúParts of the care Linda received lacked humanity. Linda just kept losing more and more weight. It was just awful. Myself and our three children kept raising it, but it wasn‚Äôt seen as a problem.

‚ÄúShe was in effect wasting away while she was in hospital. The hospital failed her. When she died, I received a letter saying she had intestinal failure, but no one had ever told us she had that.‚Äù

Her death highlights what a leading patient safety charity says is the rare but growing problem of people becoming severely malnourished while in hospital undergoing treatment.

Anna Crawford, an assistant coroner for Surrey, was so concerned by the hospital‚Äôs care of Doherty that she issued a regulation 28 report ‚Äì a warning that other patients could die unless action was taken to address flaws in its procedures for ensuring that patients were receiving proper nourishment.

She sent it to Michael Wilson, the chief executive of Surrey and Sussex Healthcare NHS trust, which runs East Surrey hospital in Redhill, demanding urgent changes to avoid a similar death. The trust said it was ‚Äúprofoundly sorry‚Äù for the inadequate care Doherty received and admitted there were ‚Äúmissed opportunities‚Äù which, if acted upon, might have saved her life.

Doherty, a 69-year-old company director, was admitted to the hospital on 8 May 2017 for bowel surgery but died three months later, on 7 August, having being an inpatient the whole time.

In her prevention of future deaths notice, the coroner found: ‚ÄúMrs Doherty succumbed to sepsis and acute kidney injury due to malnutrition. The malnutrition was caused firstly by intestinal failure due to her underlying Crohn‚Äôs disease and the reduced length of her small bowel and secondly by inadequate nutritional intake from 23 June 2017 until the time of her death.‚Äù

She criticised the hospital for a series of major errors in Doherty‚Äôs care. Staff wrongly scored her malnutrition observation charts, did not notice that her weight had dropped from 65kg to 57kg, and failed to complete charts recording her food intake for weeks at a time, ‚Äúdespite Mrs Doherty being at risk of malnutrition‚Äù.

But Crawford singled out the failure to consistently feed Doherty using total parenteral nutrition, a way of feeding a patient using a line straight into their bloodstream, bypassing their gastrointestinal tract, as a key error. ‚ÄúBut for this failure Mrs Doherty would have survived,‚Äù she said. As a result of that, ‚ÄúMrs Doherty‚Äôs death was contributed to by neglect‚Äù.

Dr Ed Cetti, the Surrey and Sussex trust‚Äôs medical director, said: ‚ÄúWe are profoundly sorry that Mrs Doherty did not receive the standard of care she or her family were entitled to expect and we offer our sincere condolences.

‚ÄúFrom the time her treatment began in 2016, there were missed opportunities that may have changed what happened while she was under our care. We accept the coroner‚Äôs findings and have put in place a range of measures to ensure this could never happen again.‚Äù

Nicola Wainwright of JMW solicitors, the family‚Äôs lawyers, said Linda died after ‚Äúgross basic failures‚Äù in her care. ‚ÄúWhen Linda started to deteriorate, nobody seems to have stopped and gone, ‚ÄòThere‚Äôs something wrong with this lady.‚Äô Instead of trying to get to the bottom of why she couldn‚Äôt eat, they told her to get on and eat, even though her intestinal failure meant that wouldn‚Äôt have made any difference.‚Äù

Peter Walsh, chief executive of patient safety charity Action against Medical Accidents, said: ‚ÄúThis kind of case is rare, but sadly we have dealt with similar cases, and the number of deaths where malnutrition in hospital is a contributory factor have been increasing. No one should die of malnutrition in hospital if they are monitored and cared for appropriately.

‚ÄúA finding of neglect by a coroner is extremely serious and is a wake-up call not just for this hospital, but across the NHS. This must not be allowed to happen again.‚Äù

headline: In brief: Leave the World Behind; The Breakup Monologues; Diving for Pearls ‚Äì reviews
standfirst: Hidden pasts in Dubai, locked-down disaster and a frank, enjoyable relationships guide
trailText: Hidden pasts in Dubai, locked-down disaster and a frank, enjoyable relationships guide
body:
Leave the World Behind

Rumaan Alam
Bloomsbury, ¬£8.99, pp256

With all the trappings of a crime drama ‚Äì mysterious strangers knock on the door and threaten to upend a family holiday ‚Äì Alam‚Äôs fascinating novel throws the kitchen sink at genre convention, mutating into a locked-down, end-of-the-world disaster story, a social satire and a comment on racial inequality and climate change. Offering no easy answers but constantly posing questions, it was published during the height of the pandemic‚Äôs first wave. Now in paperback, it has lost none of its power.

The Breakup Monologues

Rosie Wilby
Bloomsbury, ¬£16.99, pp208

Spiralling out of comedian Wilby‚Äôs profound podcast series of the same name, The Breakup Monologues is a piercingly honest look at Wilby‚Äôs own relationship history, combined with hard-won (and frequently witty) life lessons from her guests as well as therapists, sociologists and scientists. Her breezy style makes this one of the more enjoyable ‚Äì and frank ‚Äì self-help books, complete with a breakup playlist chosen in part by ex-girlfriends, wonderful stories of post-separation rediscoveries of sexuality - and the general sense that heartbreak can lead to unexpected joy, too.

Diving for Pearls

Jamie O‚ÄôConnell
Transworld, ¬£14.99, pp352

A literary thriller set in Dubai among people with hidden pasts and carefully curated versions of who they would like to be is an interesting idea. And when an Emirati woman is found dead in the marina, it sets off an intricate clash of cultures as gilded lives collide with the desperation of migrant work. O‚ÄôConnell‚Äôs debut does mainly reinforce the notion that expats are terribly entitled people but there‚Äôs nuance in the few characters desperately seeking a better, more meaningful life.

headline: Israeli opposition said to be closing in on deal to oust Netanyahu
standfirst: Reported agreement could install far-right former settler leader Naftali Bennett as prime minister
trailText: Reported agreement could install far-right former settler leader Naftali Bennett as prime minister
body:
Rival politicians in Israel united only by their opposition to Benjamin Netanyahu could be closing in on a deal to oust the country‚Äôs longest-serving leader.

The opposition leader, Yair Lapid, a former TV news anchor popular with the country‚Äôs secular middle class, has until a Wednesday deadline to build a coalition government after Netanyahu failed to do so.

Local media reports suggested Lapid, 57, had made a power-sharing offer to a political foe, Naftali Bennett, 49, a former settler leader and hard-right religious nationalist who wants to annex most of the occupied West Bank.

Bennett was due to speak on national television at 8pm local time (1700
GMT), where he is expected to confirm if he has agreed to a
power-sharing deal.

Bennett is much closer ideologically to Netanyahu than Lapid, but a deal could catapult him to high office. Under the unconfirmed agreement, Bennett, a tech millionaire who previously headed the defence and education ministries, would become prime minister for the first two years of a term, with Lapid replacing him for the final two.

Bennett gathered his Yamina party legislators on Sunday and ‚Äúreceived their unanimous support for his efforts to form a government‚Äù, according to a statement released after the meeting. It did not say whether any deal had been signed, although most Israeli media predicted that was a likely outcome.

If Lapid can get an assortment of other parties to agree in the next three days ‚Äì which is still not guaranteed ‚Äì he could inform the country‚Äôs president, Reuven Rivlin, that he believes he can form a government, which would then go to parliament, the Knesset, for a vote.

Despite vast differences, opponents of Netanyahu, who is on trial on corruption charges that he denies, have accused the 71-year-old of divisiveness and prioritising his hold on power above all else.

‚ÄúWe need a government that will reflect the fact that we don‚Äôt hate one another. A government in which left, right and centre will work together to tackle the economic and security challenges we face,‚Äù Lapid said last week.

Netanyahu‚Äôs rightwing Likud party won the most seats in a March election and was given 28 days to build a majority coalition government. He too suggested a similar power-sharing deal with Bennett but it was swiftly rejected. After the deadline passed on 5 May, Lapid was handed a mandate under Israel‚Äôs electoral system.

Lapid, once a finance minister whose Yesh Atid party came second in the last election, had sped up political consultations in recent days following a two-week bout of Gaza bloodshed that froze negotiations.

The self-proclaimed centrist and ‚Äúsecurity hawk‚Äù has sought to forge tricky alliances with parties from across the political spectrum.

He plans to bring together the establishment Labor and anti-occupation Meretz parties with their traditional enemies. They include Bennett but also Avigdor Lieberman, who once suggested that ‚Äúdisloyal‚Äù members of the country‚Äôs Arab minority, who make up about 20% of its population of 9 million, should be beheaded.

The diverse group may require outside backing by Arab members of parliament, including Islamists, who would help Lapid clinch a 61-seat majority and dethrone Netanyahu. However, their ideological differences are too great to be full coalition members, meaning Lapid would probably form a minority government.

With such significant political differences, an anti-Netanyahu coalition could be liable to break apart. To prevent that from happening, it is expected to focus on the economy and the pandemic while avoiding big issues and keeping the status quo for millions of Palestinians living under occupation.

Mossi Raz, a Meretz parliamentarian, told Israel public radio that the proposed the government ‚Äúwill do a lot of good things. I‚Äôm not sure a peace agreement will be one of them.‚Äù

If the deal is successful, it could end both a political deadlock that has brought four snap elections since 2019 and Netanyahu‚Äôs 12-year stretch as prime minister.

Netanyahu fuelled speculation that his term was about to end on Sunday by offering a last-ditch offer to Bennett and another rightwing party head, Gideon Saar. Under the deal, seen as the most generous to date from Netanyahu, the three men would each ‚Äúrotate‚Äù the role of prime minister. However, Saar, a former Netanyahu protege-turned-opponent, rejected the advance. ‚ÄúOur position and commitment was and remains to change the Netanyahu regime,‚Äù Saar tweeted.

Lapid took the role of head of the opposition from Benny Gantz, a former army chief who fought Netanyahu during the past three elections but who lost support after he made a power-sharing deal with the prime minister that ultimately collapsed.

If Lapid fails to announce a government by Wednesday, a fifth Israeli election later this year is a possible outcome.

headline: Partner of Lord Ashcroft‚Äôs son questioned over killing of Belize police officer
standfirst: Jasmin Hartin was arrested near to location of body with ‚Äòwhat appeared to be blood on her arms‚Äô
trailText: Jasmin Hartin was arrested near to location of body with ‚Äòwhat appeared to be blood on her arms‚Äô
body:
The partner of the son of Lord Ashcroft, a Conservative party donor and former treasurer, is being questioned in Belize over the killing of a police officer.

Jasmine Hartin was arrested on Friday following the discovery of the body of Supt Henry Jemmott on a pier in the resort town of San Pedro.

Hartin, 38, an American, is the partner and colleague of Ashcroft‚Äôs youngest son, Andrew. She initially refused to give a statement to the police, according to a media briefing by the police commissioner, Chester Williams. He said she would only answer questions in the presence of her lawyer.

Williams confirmed that Hartin was in custody and being investigated over the death of Jemmott. ‚ÄúUpon investigating, police found the female on a pier, and she had what appeared to be blood on her arms and on her clothing,‚Äù he said.

Speaking at a news conference on Friday he added: ‚ÄúA firearm was also seen on the pier that has been retrieved and we have learned that the firearm belonged to the police and was assigned to Mr Jemmott.‚Äù

Williams described the incident as seeming ‚Äúrather personal and not an attack‚Äù.

He said Hartin ‚Äúwas somewhat in an emotional state walking herself on the pier. We believe that she is to some extent affected by it‚Äù.

He added: ‚ÄúFrom what we know they are friends. From what we have been made to understand they were drinking. From investigation they were alone on the pier and yes, they were both fully clothed.‚Äù

According to her LinkedIn profile, Hartin is director of lifestyle and experience at the Alaia Belize hotel group, a company run by Andrew Ashcroft, 43.

The Belize police department has been contacted for an update on the investigation.

Cropping up at the bottom of gardens up and down the UK is the latest trend among the country‚Äôs home workers ‚Äì the ‚Äúshoffice‚Äù, an office in a shed.

After more than a year working from kitchen tables, sofas or spare bedrooms, many Britons are looking to carve out a quiet workspace in the loft or in their garden.

Jules Carluccio, who works in local government, is one of the millions of workers who has not been back to her usual workplace since last spring.

In anticipation of permanent home working she decided to splash out on a ‚Äúshoffice‚Äù.

The new workspace in her Bedfordshire garden is much more than a humble garden shed. At more than 8 sq metres, the wood, metal and glass structure comes complete with a canopied seating area and mains electricity. It did not come cheap at ¬£17,500.

‚ÄúIt was a big [financial] commitment, but I weighed it up,‚Äù Carluccio said. ‚ÄúI looked at how long I would be staying at the property, how long I would be in my job, and also the kinds of uses I wanted from it.‚Äù

More than a third (38%) of UK workers worked from home in mid-May, accordingto data from the Office for National Statistics.

Few office-based staff expect to go back to their desk for five days a week.

Earlier this month, the accountancy firm EY became the latest company to tell employees they will be expected to work from home for at least two days a week, even after coronavirus restrictions are lifted. Its 17,000 staff will move to a ‚Äúhybrid working model‚Äù, combining home working with the office, as well as client visits.

Many other large office occupiers plan to adopt hybrid working, to cut office costs as much as pleasing staff.

These staff need somewhere to work on the days when they are not required to be at their desk.

The booming demand for home offices pushed the company Smart Garden Rooms, Offices & Studios to its best-ever month in April, when it notched up ¬£750,000 of sales, more than double its monthly average.

Since reopening last May, the Suffolk-based firm has scarcely been able to build its garden offices quickly enough to keep up with demand, despite taking on a third more staff.

Its managing director, Matt Moss, said: ‚ÄúPeople don‚Äôt spend ¬£20,000 on a garden room on a whim, thinking I might be able to work from home going forward. People are committed to this.‚Äù

‚ÄúOur level of enquiries amazes us every single day; that it is so consistent,‚Äù he said, adding that ‚Äúshoffices‚Äù usually do not require planning permission.

The trend is being repeated elsewhere. Sales of garden buildings rocketed by 500% between January and May, compared with a year earlier, while sales of sheds soared by more than 460%, according to the DIY and building supplies retailer Toolstation.

Workers‚Äô desire to create an office away from the office is also inspiring some to move upstairs. On England‚Äôs south coast, the Brighton Loft Company has had an 80% increase in inquiries during the pandemic, which its owner, Gilles Buxton, ascribes to demand for home offices.

body:
When Dominic Cummings gave evidence to MPs last week, few cabinet ministers came away unscathed. But one man suffered the most: Matt Hancock. While the former senior No 10 aide pulled no punches with his former boss, Boris Johnson ‚Äì declaring him unfit to lead ‚Äì it was the health secretary who ended up bearing the brunt of Cummings‚Äô attacks.

Among the various missiles Cummings launched were claims that Hancock ought to have been sacked already for ‚Äú15 to 20 things‚Äù, and was guilty of ‚Äúcriminal, disgraceful behaviour that caused serious harm‚Äù. The most serious allegation is that Hancock lied about protecting care homes from Covid in March ‚Äì telling the prime minister residents would be tested before being sent back from hospital when that wasn‚Äôt the case.

Five days on ‚Äì and despite a carefully worded denial by the health secretary that he committed to delivering that testing ‚Äúwhen we could do it‚Äù ‚Äì the story refuses to go away. As new reports emerge of Hancock being cut out of No 10 meetings last year and of questionable Department of Health guidance from that time, questions are being asked over Hancock‚Äôs future. The latest Opinium poll found that 44% of respondents believed he should resign.

They may be disappointed. Unless new evidence comes to light, few in government believe Hancock is going anywhere soon. It‚Äôs not just that the prime minister tends to suffer from what one close ally describes as ‚Äúbroken bird syndrome‚Äù, and rarely wants to sack people ‚Äì ‚Äúthe more criticised someone is, the more he wants to support them‚Äù ‚Äì it‚Äôs also the fact that the accuser is Cummings. For Johnson, this isn‚Äôt just about an allegation of ministerial wrongdoing: it is about who now calls the shots in 10 Downing Street.

To say relations between Boris Johnson and Dominic Cummings are at a low ebb would be an understatement. Even if the Tories retain their poll lead over Labour, the prime minister is bruised by the whole affair. Johnson was already known as someone who took a long time to place his trust in people, and he now trusts even fewer people than usual. These days, when things go wrong in Downing Street, blame is often placed on his former aide. Those in the building who are seen to have been close with Cummings and the Vote Leave team are regarded with suspicion.

This is why the vicious tone of Cummings‚Äô attacks is likely to provide the health secretary some protection. ‚ÄúMatt is safer than people think,‚Äù says one adviser to the government. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs very ‚Äòmy enemy‚Äôs enemy is my friend‚Äô in there at the moment.‚Äù If anything, there is more suspicion on a political level in No 10 towards the cabinet ministers who fared well in the session. The lengthy praise of the chancellor, Rishi Sunak, did not go unnoticed, and neither did the fact Cummings‚Äô old boss, Michael Gove, was barely mentioned despite his being a key figure in the Covid response.

What‚Äôs more, were Johnson to turn on Hancock, it could turn attention back to Cummings‚Äô criticism of the prime minister. Given that Cummings had plenty of negative things to say about Johnson, conceding he was on to something with Hancock could suggest he has a point about the prime minister too. Johnson and his team are reluctant to hand Cummings a scalp.

But that‚Äôs not to say that Hancock‚Äôs future in government is rosy. There are plenty of current and former aides who will attest to the fact Hancock‚Äôs relationship with the prime minister was strained in the early stages of the pandemic. The relationship hit a low over the PPE shortage ‚Äì which No 10 aides squarely blamed on Hancock. It wasn‚Äôt uncommon to hear Downing Street aides distinguish ‚Äúfacts‚Äù from what they jokingly called ‚ÄúHancock facts‚Äù.

On the other side, those working in the Department of Health often found No 10 hard to work with. The fact Cummings admitted in the evidence session that, as Hancock tried to reach his 100,000 tests a day target last spring, people were calling around saying ‚Äúdo not do what Hancock says‚Äù has only confirmed their sense that No 10 would often obstruct them. ‚ÄúImagine working with someone like that every day,‚Äù says one ally of the health secretary.

The widespread dislike of Cummings is also helping Hancock when it comes to the parliamentary party ‚Äì the majority of whom are taking the character assassination with a pinch of salt. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm not Matt‚Äôs biggest fan, but we know Dom isn‚Äôt a Tory and he has an agenda,‚Äù says one senior MP. ‚ÄúHe doesn‚Äôt seem to know what middle ground is, either someone is a one out of 10 or they‚Äôre amazing. Why is no one a six?‚Äù The only Tory MP to publicly put his head above the parapet is Dan Poulter, who has called for an immediate inquiry into what happened in Britain‚Äôs care homes.

With Hancock‚Äôs position regarded as secure for now, the more immediate question is whether he can retain authority in his department ‚Äì at a time when the ministers plan to assume more power over the NHS as part of a shake-up of the healthcare system. But the situation could still change. It is perhaps unsurprising the Tory party would prefer to take Hancock‚Äôs word over that of a man who they believe won‚Äôt stop until he has brought down the government.

New evidence or documents relating to Cummings‚Äô claims could change the calculation. Cummings has repeatedly said he has messages to back up his claims and has been asked to supply these to MPs leading the committee inquiry. New witnesses, too, to the Commons inquiry (and later the official one) could move the dial if they corroborate Cummings‚Äôs claims.

‚ÄúWe‚Äôll stand up for him but not in the same way we would Priti,‚Äù says one 2019-er, referring to the home secretary, who is popular with the party membership and seen to closer reflect the electoral interests of the new electoral coalition. Meanwhile, lockdown-sceptic Tories have long been critical of the minister they believe to be one of the chief doves.

For now, however, Hancock has the backing of the prime minister. So long as that remains beneficial for both sides, he will be safe.
